title: Disclosure of ip addresses in local network of uber
vulnerability_information:
Hi, i have found several DNS records at Google DNS server 8.8.8.8 pointing to Uber local servers:

```
▶ nslookup logs.uber.com
Server:		8.8.8.8
Address:	8.8.8.8#53

Non-authoritative answer:
Name:	logs.uber.com
Address: 10.6.0.1
```

```
▶ nslookup kerberos.uber.com
Server:		8.8.8.8
Address:	8.8.8.8#53

Non-authoritative answer:
Name:	kerberos.uber.com
Address: 10.6.0.74
```

```
▶ nslookup ldap.uber.com
Server:		8.8.8.8
Address:	8.8.8.8#53

Non-authoritative answer:
Name:	ldap.uber.com
Address: 10.30.14.3
```

This information could be used, if attacker gets SSRF,XXE,LFI etc in order to address local network of Uber.
vulnerability_information_html:
Hi, i have found several DNS records at Google DNS server 8.8.8.8 pointing to Uber local servers:

▶ nslookup logs.uber.com
Server:     8.8.8.8
Address:    8.8.8.8#53

Non-authoritative answer:
Name:   logs.uber.com
Address: 10.6.0.1

▶ nslookup kerberos.uber.com
Server:     8.8.8.8
Address:    8.8.8.8#53

Non-authoritative answer:
Name:   kerberos.uber.com
Address: 10.6.0.74

▶ nslookup ldap.uber.com
Server:     8.8.8.8
Address:    8.8.8.8#53

Non-authoritative answer:
Name:   ldap.uber.com
Address: 10.30.14.3

This information could be used, if attacker gets SSRF,XXE,LFI etc in order to address local network of Uber.

activities.message:
Thanks for your report.

We appreciate you sending this in. Unfortunately the behavior described here is not, in itself, dangerous enough to Uber or Uber's customers/clients to be eligible for this program.

Thanks and good luck with future bug hunting.
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks for your report.

We appreciate you sending this in. Unfortunately the behavior described here is not, in itself, dangerous enough to Uber or Uber's customers/clients to be eligible for this program.

Thanks and good luck with future bug hunting.

activities.message:
Please disclose if that is OK.

Thanks

Hi again.

2 months later i have come up with an idea how to exploit this.


Idea
==============
* Being on the same network, attacker creates a phishing page at the specified local address for a victim
* Attacker delivers one of Uber's URL (related to specified misconfigured DNS record) to victim's browser
* ???
* PROFIT!!! Victim is at phishing page

Example
===============

logs.uber.com is resolved into 10.6.0.1.
```
▶ nslookup logs.uber.com
Server:     8.8.8.8
Address:    8.8.8.8#53

Non-authoritative answer:
Name:   logs.uber.com
Address: 10.6.0.1
```
If an attacker creates a phishing website on this IP and delivers http://logs.uber.com URL to victim's browser, victim is going to be redirected straight to this phishing page without noticing anything bad, as URL seems to be valid Uber address.

Summary 
==============
This bug requires some specified conditions, but is still valid in common cases. E.x. evil network at some mall, deployed using Pineapple WiFi.

So could please recheck this submission?

Anatoly Ivanov
